swift/obj/expirer.py.message: Sigh, this wsgistr stuff will forever be the bane of our existance.. thanks for continuing to remind us how it works Tim :P

Wait a moment, delete_object just does make_path and then make_request. Surely it wants a wsgi a, c, o. Right? But the expirer appears to manipulate with straight-up unicode when composing task lists. Maybe I'm just confused.

The wsgi dance I introduced in https://review.opendev.org/#/c/659189/ was probably unnecessary; internal_client's interface deals in native strings (and, on py2, unicode strings -- I should probably make it behave better with bytes on py3...)

So, we hand native strings to delete_object, make_path ensures it's all quoted (using a utf8 encoding) as we pass it to swob.Request.blank, which then unquotes it using latin1 to get us back to WSGI. Blech.
so i guess the `'/' + actual_object('/')` was mostly being defensive to the tests?
so the "bug" as it were was NOT calling drain_and_close on the resp returned here
the target_path does not include the leading `/`
delete_object gets the whole task dict
and target_path is passed through unmolested to delete_actual_object
maybe it'd be more clear if the signature carried forward the "target_path" name from the "delete_task"
it's a little hard to see because this is so dense, but the signature is delete_object(a, c, o, **kwargs) - and under the hood it's using make_path to add the `/v1` for the IC request.

neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/agent/ne.message:
Let's say we have Chassis_Private support--in which case the chassis_private variable is actually a Chassis_Private. In this case, the old code would check for ovn-cms-options on that Chassis_Private.external_ids. This new code would try to look up the Chassis on the Chassis_Private--which would exist, and look for the option there. So this would change where we look for that option.

So I'm confused how the original code works for when Chassis_Private support exists--because ovn-controller sets ovn-cms-options on the Chassis, and not the Chassis_Private. So it looks like this patch would fix that bug as well if I'm reading things correctly? Thoughts?

If so, then we can also get rid of some code duplication of the try/except by having a staticmethod NeutronAgent.chassis_from_private(maybe_private) that basically does what NeutronAgent.chassis property does, and have the property return self.chassis_from_private(self.chassis_private) and have ControllerAgent.__new__ call cls.chassis_from_private(chassis_private) and get the external_ids from there. But I'm also ok with just going with the patch as-is if you don't feel like making the change.

Also, for a while now the primary place that ovn-cms-options has been set is on Chassis.other-config (it is, for now, copied to external_ids as well, but will be removed at some point). So we could handle that case as well.

1. The original code doesn't work properly when Chassis_Private support exists.[1]
2. I add a staticmethod NeutronAgent.chassis_from_private
3. Several places from external_ids read ovn-cms-options, ovn-bridge-mappings ..., is it possible to switch from ovn when it is not supported.

glance/db/sqlalchemy/api.py.message: Just noticed that this doesn't actually look at the 'deleted' column (but the purge code doesn't, either, so this isn't something you need to address in this patch, though other reviewers may feel differently).  That's why we tell people it's not a good idea to modify the DB by hand!  A script that put a deleted_at time on non-deleted images probably wouldn't affect glance's normal functioning until someone does a db purge or obfuscate, and then those images might all disappear or be obfuscated, regardless of not actually being deleted.

Two things about this:

(1) it's defined in the sqlalchemy model as a boolean [0], so I think you should have a boolean value here, not an int.  (It shows up in mysql/mariadb as a tinyint(1), but at this layer, we should be using the ORM values or we'll run into something like https://bugs.launchpad.net/glance/+bug/1749297 if someone uses postgres)

(2) the default is False, but you are setting it to True (just wondering if there was a reason not to use the default?)


[0] https://github.com/openstack/glance/blob/37babc4eb10091601d5a124fa1072011fcb7c4b3/glance/db/sqlalchemy/models.py#L143-L144
The only reason is because I though it is a more reasonable value for an obfuscate image. But I don't have a strong opinion on this.
Default for this is 'shared', but i think it's good to have 'private' here (which is what we're trying to get the default to be, eventually).
The same reason as the previous.
Basically, same comment as for 'protected', above.
Again, I don't have a strong argument. Just felt a better value for an obfuscated image. But probably I'm wrong.

nova/compute/resource_tracker.py.message: This might be the key. If we want to downgrade the warning, we could consider just doing that if the instance.task_state is not None.

Yup, this is the key. However, the instance.task_state is not necessarily able to determine whether the final result of the instance operation (evacuate, shelve offload, cold or live migrate) conforms to the scenario. That whole block does need to be re-worked.
The code referenced here is all long gone and doesn't apply anymore.
Yeah, these desc are not means, should be removed.
Hmm, I think we should probably keep the original statement as this is not only used for live migration, in other cases, the instance did moved to other host permanently
Agree that this isn't really a temporary thing if we're in the middle of a migration.

The original warning was likely because this was worried about leaking allocations if the source compute didn't clean them up, but really that's the job of the migration code to do the allocation cleanup properly on whatever host, for whatever move operation (evacuate, shelve offload, cold or live migrate).

As such the warning shouldn't really apply anymore, especially if the instance task_state is not None. If the task_state is None and we have allocations against this host but that's not where the instance is, then the warning is probably OK.

metalsmith/_nics.py.message:
I'm going to second Dmitry's statement. This just feels wrong to send none, or a dummy value. It feels like a deficiency of the API and that we're routing around designed mechanisms/models of use.

It almost feels like, the requirement might need to be dropped from the Neutron side for it to be truly useful in a standalone case anyway, given the project id is a construct of user pooling from Keystone to begin with.
Not sure I understand. Neutron does expect a project_id in request if X-Project-Id is not in header.

No, using custom policy won't suffice, as there are embeded logic in the api layer to use project_id. I had a chat with Akihiro-san and he has updated the bug https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1934039/comments/5

tenant_id attribute is required_by_policy for POST requests[1] and enforced by the neutron policy engine since long. I don't know how it would disappear from neutron API any time.

As for making changes to neutron to behave differently, I don't know what all needs to be changed, but I suspect it's probably going to be a very big change and won't fly.

My understanding is metalsmith is consuming neutron API and when the neutron API changes (and is not backward compatible), it would change as well.    


[1] https://github.com/openstack/neutron-lib/blob/master/neutron_lib/api/definitions/port.py#L90

I've reported a neutron bug https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1934039 for this and would work with the neutron folks to chage it along with support for 'http_basic' auth_strategy.

With that as a way forward, would we be ok to merge this workaround to get us moving?
Per https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1934039/comments/1 it seems to be a neutron misconfiguration.

I've expressed my opinion on https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1934039/comments/7. If the neutron team doesn't care about this, I will recommend you keep Keystone or drop both Neutron and Keystone altogether.
If neutron doesn't want to properly support no-auth, we probably don't either, and you definitely should not try to use it in TripleO. Keystone is not a heavyweight service to deploy.

That is true that neutron requires project id to be set always for most of the resources: https://github.com/openstack/neutron-lib/blob/master/neutron_lib/db/model_base.py#L22
We have same problem now with SYSTEM scoped personas with new RBAC policies as there is no project_id in context so we need to pass project_id in the request body.
Sending some dummy value will work from the neutron PoV unless You will not have "project_id" filter enabled: https://github.com/openstack/neutron/commit/2df49fa879eda377c6f7489cfbe0659be29d2366
I know it's not perfect solution but I think that for now it's the only possible workaround here.

manilaclient/v2/shell.py.message:
unfortunately the "status" attribute on a snapshot does not tell you whether the access rules are applied or not. You'll need to look at the snapshot access rule and figure that out. To see how to retrieve the access available, see the "do_snapshot_access_list" method in this file. You can get the snapshot's access rules and then wait until the state has been set to "active"

   accesses = share_snapshot.access_list()
   this_rule = [acc for acc in accesses if acc['id'] == access['id']][0]
   # this_rule['state'] == 'active'? if not, repeat your check

   finally, print this_rule.
No need to print the share snapshot. The access rule needs to be printed

You can only specify one snapshot, and many rule IDs
so no need for this variabl, and for the loop on line 1919

Unfortunately, there is no "status" change in the snapshot when access rules are denied. I would suggest using the same pattern as above:

  for access_id in args.id:
      accesses = snapshot.access_list()
      # wait until args.id isn't in accesses.
This needn't be printed here anymore; you can wait to print it if --wait is provided

This logic is incorrect. What it is currently doing is reading the access list, and printing the entry from the list, it isn't really "wait"ing for anything to happen. What should happen is in the following pseudocode:

 while True:
    a) Read the access list
    b) Extract the specific access rule from the access list
    c) Check the "state" attribute on the rule
    d) If the "state" is "active" or "error", bail out of the loop

Once you've implemented this core logic, we can make some improvements:

1) If the access state reaches "error", you need to print the access rule (using cliutils.print_dict) and raise a CommandError
2) You can't be in an infinite waiting loop. You need some criteria to get out of the loop if the state never changes. That criteria is a timeout. Take a look at how timeout is implemented in the other waiters: https://github.com/openstack/python-manilaclient/blob/1075210b959da0daa613aaaf4f60f4b7810071f2/manilaclient/v2/shell.py#L74-L92
3) This logic can be extracted into a method instead of being directly in line with the code. You can re-use the same logic for the "deny_access" waiter below.

I am not sure i understand the intent here. If i read this right, you're looping through the rules being deleted and printing the rule as you find them. That isn't what you want... 

You should be waiting until the rules are all deleted. A rule is deleted when it stops being in the response of the access_list on line 1918.

can we call this "action" instead of "expected"?

did you mean to make this a keyword argument? your method invocation on 1903 and 1953 is as if this were a keyword argument...
this needs to be passed to this method, instead of passing the whole access dict, just pass access_id from the calling method

Change this check and the check on line 215 to 

  'error' in this_rule['state']

It's better future proofing, since we could have states that have the word "error" in them
this isn't required. Please see comment above on how to check for rules to disappear from the access_list - we don't need to print anything when denying rules
you'll need to wait for each rule in args.id, see loop on line 1939.
nit: try..except around lines 205-206, not share_snapshot.access_list()
nit: please see pep8 conventions on how to format this code: https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0008/#indentation

As this will be mapped to CUSTOM_ RC in placement we need to implement and document restriction of the value. Placement enforces a [A-Z0-9_] (note that it is all capital) character set and 255 max length (including the CUSTOM_ prefix) for the RC names. Alternatively we can try to translate to that charset. Still I think it is better to restrict than to translate.
OK. So if the mdev_class == vgpu then rc_name will be VGPU (non custom) but in every other case we use f"CUSTOM_{mdev_class.upper()}". This is fine for me.

In practice the libvirt driver needs to look at every CUSTOM_ RC in the incoming allocation and figure out what needs to be mapped to an MDEV. It should not be an error if there is allocation to other CUSTOM_ RCs that cannot be mapped to an MDEV device.

I'm wondering that having only a mdev_class that is encoded in a CUSTOM_ RC means that deployers will encode not only quantitative but also qualitative information in the name of the RC. For qualitative information we have traits in placement. 

For example: A deployer has a compute with two pGPUs both MDEV capable, supporting 4 vGPUs each. But one of the pGPU is a newer model, causing that vGPUs from it has a better performance. With the current proposal deployer can only encode this difference in the mdev_class and hence in the CUSTOM_ RC name. E.g.:

  [devices]
  enabled_mdev_types = vgpu_slow, vgpu_fast
  [mdev_vgpu_slow]
  device_addresses = 0000:84:00.0
  mdev_class=vgpu_slow
  [mdev_vgpu_fast]
  device_addresses = 0000:85:00.0
  mdev_class=vgpu_fast

Then the deployer creates two different flavors one referring to CUSTOM_VGPU_SLOW the other referring to CUSTOM_VGPU_FAST. This works so far.

However the deployer cannot create flavors expressing the give-me-a-vgpu-i-dont-care-how-fast-it-is case. For this to be expressible the qualitative part of the resource would need to be represented with a trait instead of an RC. Then a trait can be required in the flavor to get a fast vGPU or can be omitted to get any (fast or slow) vGPU.

One way to do this is to add an extra 'mdev_traits' config option which would be a list of string. Nova would map that to CUSTOM_ traits. Or alternatively we can tell the deployer to use provider.yaml but it would be strange to set the RC by nova.conf but the trait by provider.yaml.

Well, two thoughts :

1/ VGPU types exist for this.
For example, for the same GPU, you can ask for a few fast vGPUs or a lot of slow vGPUs.
Example with a V100 : V100-1A gives me a large number of vGPUs while V100-16C gives you max performance for AI.
https://docs.nvidia.com/grid/latest/grid-vgpu-user-guide/index.html#vgpu-types-tesla-v100-pcie

2/ Also, for the usecase, we provided a documentation explaining how to use custom traits : https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/admin/virtual-gpu.html#optional-provide-custom-traits-for-multiple-gpu-types

So, I guess that's maybe something we could eventually do, but this is unrelated to the spec here and should be discussed in another spec.

We discussed it on IRC[1] with Sylvain and Sean and I think I see now how this works.

So the deployer can specify two mdev types in the config with the same mdev_class value to put them into the same resource pool, then the deployer can use custom traits to still differentiate between the two mdev types that are pooled in the same RC. That logic works for me and that preserves the current vgpu logic where every vgpu type is pooled into the same VGPU resource inventory. 

We agreed that some documentation needed that encourages the deployer to use custom traits instead of encoding qualitative information into the mdev_class name.

zuul/zk/executor.py.message:
Based on my understanding of the DataWatch (and now ExistingDataWatch) class, I believe there will not be a separate deleted event, because:

1) If we were using DataWatch, the watcher would be set via the "exists" call, and so the next callback would only happen if a new znode were created at that path.
2) But since we're using the new ExistingDataWatch (because the above doesn't make sense for us), there will be no watcher set at this point.  The return value in this case does not matter.
Not sure if we should return False in this case to stop the data watch or if there will be a separate DELETED event.

neutron_lib/api/definitions/rbac_bgpvpn..message:
So this is a readonly field, not like other resources' shared?

https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lib/src/branch/master/neutron_lib/api/definitions/subnetpool.py#L100
https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lib/src/branch/master/neutron_lib/api/definitions/network.py#L65

Yes, readonly. Because POST/PUT requests cannot manage resources provided from service plugin. Neutron's RBAC system will not find it. Only if the main resource (in this case 'bgpvpn') will have OVO object definition it will work. But in this case OVO object will conflict with API extension provided from service plugin. So it's impossible.

In a Telco Service Provider environment, we run VNFs (Virtual Network Functions) & CNFs (Containerized-Network-Functions)  that each provide from simple-to-fairly complex services to subscribers.  In order provide such services, within these VNFs we run applications that use many Non-Neutron IP-Addresses which need to be exposed to subscribers. It is through these Non-Neutron IP-Addresses the subscribers access the services provided by the VNFs (and CNFs). We refer such IPAddresses generically as 'Service-Address'.  These 'Service-Address' can belong to either IPv4 (or) IPv6 address-families.

Service-Address are wholly managed inside a VNF transparent to Neutron, but reaching these Service-Address on the dataplane by subscribers is enabled through VNICs (or Ports) holding Neutron-managed Addresses.   Basically, the Neutron managed primary-addresses on VNFs VNICs act as NextHops enabling reachability to the Service-Address held inside by applications inside the VNF.

In order to enable L3 reachability to these Service-Addresses from an ISP-network (or) say from say another-internal-network entity,  these Service-Addresses need to be brought into a Neutron Router's Routing Table.  The #ofVNFs are high and thence the #ofserviceaddresses to be exposed are even more higher.

Under this situation, using "BGP between the VNFs and their hosting Neutron Routers" provides a very elegant and scalable automated approach to drive control-plane driven route-learning of Service-Address by the Neutron Router from the VNFs.   This as a consequence enables L3 reachability of such Service-Addresses to internal-network-entities.

So FIRST-USE-CASE that this Spec will address is enabling direct BGP-Peering from a Neutron Router towards the VNFs (or CNFs) on its connected networks.

Now having the Service-Address hosted in the Neutron Router is alone not sufficient.  Such addresses need to be advertised to the ISP-PE-Router, as only that will enable subscribers present on ISP-network be able to use the services exported by applications in the VNFs.

And, so the SECOND-USE-CASE that this Spec will address is to enable BGP-Peering over Neutron External Networks from a Neutron Router to the ISP-PE-Router.   This will end up making the PE-Router learn the Service-Addresses over the BGP control plane, thereby enabling L3-reachability for subscribers on the ISP-side to be able to take advantage of services offered by VNFs (and CNFs).
Done
The above lines from 25 to 36 might not be required if the previous comment is accepted.

The two use-cases we mentioned above are not available today in existing BGPaaS, as existing BGPaaS supports BGP Peering only over Non-Neutron Networks.   Please refer the current implementation and documentation as in [9].   
So existing BGPaaS mechanism lacks the functionality (both API and implementations) to do BGP Peering over Neutron External Networks as well as it lacks mechanisms to do BGP Peering over Neutron Internal Tenant Networks.

Here at the top let me summarize some concerns raised on the PTG (mostly by Miguel Lavalle, please correct me Miguel if I misunderstood something):

1) Previously all dynamic routing functionality was implemented in the neutron-dynamic-routing repo. Can we implement everything proposed here in the neutron-dynamic-routing repo? Clearly we can do that for all service plugin modifications and hopefully for all l3-agent modifications via using an agent extension. However I'm not familiar with agent extensions, so I'm not sure about the latter. We definitely cannot have code in the neutron repo that depends on code in the n-d-r repo.

2) Does the implementation of this proposal replace the already existing n-d-r?
Is the functionality proposed here a clear superset of the already existing functionality?
(For example will the implementation proposed here be able to handle speaker-net associations?)
Will we have the functional enhancements proposed here available for speakers associated with networks?

The way I understand the current proposal is the following:
The API is extended so a speaker can be associated with either networks or a router, but never both.
The modified service plugin based on the association (whether it's a network(s) or a router) calls into the pre-existing dr-agent (for the network association) or into a newly modified l3-agent (for the router association.)

However as pointed out on the PTG, this may lead to two separately maintained n-d-r implementations (below the point in the service plugin where the line of control differs). The two also possibly functionally diverging. The duplication raising the maintenance cost.

How do we plan to address these concerns? For example: Could we have a shared codebase which can be deployed both as a standalone agent (for backwards compatibility) and inside the l3-agent namespace?
Point 1 seems to be a better approach with probably common shared codebase. I will go through different possibilities and then come back with a better answer.

Since not everybody in the Neutron community is from a Telco company it may make sense to mention the non-Telco names of these things, for example:

* VNFs : VMs running apps
* ISP PE router : the first router north of the neutron router
Will be updated in next patch set

These VNF service addresses are not known to the neutron. They are internal to the VNFs and used between each other in a VNF cluster and outside. AFAIU, these addresses are managed by the VNFs.

Can we delete a peer group when there are peers belonging to it? Probably we should allow that, otherwise we may have a race between deleting the peer group and peering connections creating new peers.
Done

I think we should not allow peer groups to be deleted when there are peers belonging to it.
If we allow then it might get more complicated. We might need to track and delete all the peers wherever peer_group_id is referenced.

Continuing the thought from line 364: In the POST request we have the peer_group_id, however we probably don't want to have a peer_group_id attribute for the peer object, so we can delete the peer group without creating dangling references.

Or even: why do we even need an API to create peers from peer groups? We already have a way to create peers, and the peer group feature would create the peers based on peer groups implicitly, not via the API.

Having the option for a peer group to be active/inactive (taking connections or not) is another way to handle the problem. I'm not sure how the solution can be purely solved inside os-ken (but please see option B below). I see the following workflow options to delete a peer group:

option A: peers created in peer groups have the group as a parent object, dangling references are not allowed)
step 1) inactivate the peer group (for example a peer group update setting active=False)
step 2) list all peers belonging to it
step 3) delete them
step 4) delete the peer group itself

option B: peers created in peer groups have the group as a parent object, the deletion of a peer group automatically deletes all of the peers belonging to it)
step 1) delete the peer group
In this case the inactivation of the the peer group probably can be handled implicitly and pushed down to os-ken to handle it. However this means that the active/inactive property of a peer group cannot be observed on the API. And it also leads to  cascaded API operation which very easily leads to the trigger operation taking a long time and overrunning client side timeouts. Also cascading API operations are unusual in the Neutron API.

option C: peer groups are used as templates, peers created from peer groups do not have any reference to the group used in creation)
This is problematic because we have no direct information to delete all peers "belonging"/created from a peer group.

option D: peer groups are used as templates, peers created from peer groups have no parent object, but they have a history-like reference to the group they were created from, in this field we allow that the referenced peer group does not exist anymore)
step 1) delete the peer group
step 2) list all peers referencing the peer group just deleted
step 3) delete them

I see options A and D as correct solutions - B and C seem to be problematic. To me D seems conceptually simpler, but this is just a question of taste, I can easily accept option A too.
If you prefer option A, then let's add the 'enable' attribute to the peer group API.

This is an answer to both lines 364 and 373.

For the 2nd use case I believe we already have good tools via using HOT templates. So I don't think we need to solve this in neutron.

What made me think here is the following problem: If we allow automatic creation of peers belonging to a peer group, then how do we delete peer groups? We may end up racing with peer creation.

One idea I had to avoid this problem is to treat the peer group not as a parent object, but as a template: At the time of peer creation its attributes get copied to the peer, but after creation the peer no longer has the group as its parent. If the group is only a template, then there's no dangling reference problem. On the other hand it's harder/impossible to find out which peers got auto-created (unless we do something about that).

Please also think about group updates: If I update an attribute of a group, does that automatically update the same attribute of all the peers belonging to the group? I believe it's better not to allow this "cascading" update.

Between the ns-only and the mixed options I see a tradeoff:
* the ns-only option is a smaller change, with lower overall code complexity, but
* the mixed option provides a way forward for possibly better scalability

I'm not sure which one is finally the better choice, but in order to keep our options open I'd suggest:

1) Making it optional in the BGP speaker whether it uses a NS or a VRF.
2) If we ever want to support the mixed option, then the BGP speaker cannot use the addresses of the router interfaces. We should not make assumptions about the router interface and bgp speaker address being the same. Plus if we want to allow the remote party to initiate bgp peering then we also most expose the speaker address in the API somewhere.

I will add an attribute to specify whether to use ns or vrf in the next patchset.  Mixed option seems to be a complex one to implement. Probably we can move from option 1 to 3 with your suggestion no 1. Hope this will also solve the upgrade issue.

Yes, new ports are created for this on br-int
I can see this option only in parallel with the existing namespace based l3, perhaps with a deprecation path to the old ns based one if we can provide full parity with VRFs.

If the level of isolation between VRFs is sufficient for us then I believe this could be a valid long term goal, because it likely improves performance/scalability. However I don't see an upgrade path from namespaces to VRFs without some traffic loss. Because of that I believe we must provide a gradual way of replacement, in which the operator is free to decide when to do the upgrade. Therefore I think it's not an option to go directly for this.

Also for keeping the scope here minimal and to avoid introducing big prerequisites I suggest to address the replacement of namespaces with VRFs in a standalone spec (if/whenever we get there).

BGPaaS is an advanced capability that is provided in Neutron.  Different Neutron backends will have varying implementations to provide this capability.  So it would be good to have some feedback ingrained in the Neutron BGPaaS API through which various Neutron backends (including our reference BGPaaS backend) can drive realization status inside Openstack Infra for the BGP resources exposed by Neutron BGPaaS.   To that direction, we are proposing in this Spec to add a new resource type 'Association' that can work with current BGPSpeaker object.  More specifically, we are planning to support router_association, peer_association as resources under a BGPSpeaker object.   A 'router_association' resource will be used to create a binding between a BGPSpeaker and a Neutron Router, that internally realizes BGP Control Plane over that Neutron Router.  Similarly, a "peer_association' resource will be used to create a binding between a BGPSpeaker and a BGPPeer , that internally realized BGP Peering between the BGPSpeaker and the BGPPeer resource.

ironic/drivers/modules/redfish/raid.py.message: So the field that raid_types is based on is SupportedRAIDTypes which came in v1.6+ of the schema 2018.3. I suspect if not present this may not work, so *likely* at a minimum release note worthy.

if not present, then sushy returns raid_types = None and then this is false. If can't know if this is RAID controller or not, then still try with it and possibly fail at later stage if somehow all the logic here decides to use physical disks of controller not capable of RAID.

If different behavior is necessary, then it can be updated accordingly. I went with this option as it's the same workflow as it is without this change and don't see alternative way to determine RAID capability without SupportedRAIDTypes.

This change helps those who implement SupportedRAIDTypes and does not change anything for those who don't.
Maybe even "not controller.raid_types" to also exclude None?
Mmm, yeah, I think I see the reason.

for now it's on purpose to check only [] to allow None for systems that haven't implemented raid_types. Thinking a bit - I'll check if I can get more information about such systems and what is better - to include or exclude None.

templates/overcloud_upgrade_run.sh.j2.message:
There's an unnecessary loop here (the outer loop), and a logic error (the sleep should happen after the elapsed time check).

Suggested edit:

timeout_seconds=100
elapsed_seconds=0

echo "[($date) Waiting for compute services to be up]"
source {{ overcloud_rc }}

while ! openstack compute service list -c State -f value | grep -q down; do
    if [ $elapsed_seconds -ge $timeout_seconds]; then
        echo "FAILURE: Some compute services are still down"
        openstack compute service list
        exit 1
    fi
    sleep 2
    elapsed_seconds=$(expr $elapsed_seconds + 2)
done
echo "All compute services are up and running"
This should be the same as the change above. In fact, why not make it a function to deduplicate the code?

Arrgggh...right.. thanks for catching that, I missed it. Agree on the function part, I just want to test the patch in the CI job (see if it helps solving the issue) and then I'll address the DRY issue. So you can keep your -1 until I change it.
I think it'd be best to turn this into a function to deduplicate the code.

templates/workload_launch.sh.j2.message: These changes seem out of scope?
Agree, I'll changer them back in next patchset.

This needs to be changed, as right now as soon as all compute services are up we get out from the loop. After testing with Sergii, this approach would work better:

    until openstack compute service list --service nova-compute -c State -f value | grep -qv down && openstack network agent list -f value -c Alive | grep -qv False; do                       
        if [ $elapsed_seconds -ge $timeout_seconds ]; then                                                                                                                                     
            echo "FAILURE: Some nova-compute or neutron services are down"                                                                                                                     
            openstack compute service list --service nova-compute                                                                                                                              
            openstack network agent list                                                                                                                                                       
            exit 1                                                                                                                                                                             
        fi                                                                                                                                                                                     
        sleep 5                                                                                                                                                                                
        elapsed_seconds=$(( ${elapsed_seconds} + 5 ))                                                                                                                                          
    done                                                                                                                                                                                       
    echo "All compute services are up and running"

Maybe better to make this two loops - first compute, then network, then perhaps also cinder-volume too?

There are some hard-won lessons learned in https://github.com/redhat-openstack/infrared/blob/master/plugins/virsh/snapshot_quiesce.yml which may be useful for inspiration.
Well, 2 loops are 2 times slower in worst case scenario but I will rework in next patchset.
Good catch, this probably got lost on the way...
